docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. George E. Pataki and the majority leader of the State Senate, Joseph L. Bruno, threw their support today behind a proposed law that would give patients access to information about doctors whose insurance companies had settled malpractice claims against them. In so doing, Mr. Bruno and Mr. Pataki, both Republicans, joined Democratic Assembly leaders who passed a similar proposal last year. That proposal died in the Senate, where Mr. Bruno tightly controls all legislation, and many Democrats concluded that Mr. Bruno had opposed it.

headline.main: Pataki and Bruno Back Bill to Let Patients See Malpractice Data on Doctors

docs.snippet: Gov. George E. Pataki and the majority leader of the State Senate, Joseph L. Bruno, threw their support today behind a proposed law that would give patients access to information about doctors whose insurance companies had settled malpractice claims...

docs.lead_paragraph: Disappointed investors drove shares of Aetna Inc. down $5.25 yesterday, or 9 percent, to $50.75, after Aetna rejected an offer to hold discussions on a tentative takeover bid valued at $70 a share, or $9.9 billion, by WellPoint Health Networks and the ING Group of insurance and financial services companies. William H. Donaldson, chief executive of Aetna, said there would be antitrust and other problems in combining with WellPoint which, he said, is ''a much smaller'' health insurer than Aetna. He insisted that his team, which plans to split Aetna into two independent companies, could do a better job than WellPoint and ING of reviving Aetna's stock price.

headline.main: Takeover Hopes Squelched, Shares of Aetna Fall 9%

docs.abstract: Disappointed investors drive shares of Aetna Inc down 9 percent after Aetna rejects offer to hold discussions on tentative takeover bid valued at $9.9 billion by WellPoint Health Networks and ING Group; Aetna chief executive William H Donaldson says there will be antitrust and other problems in combining with WellPoint; ING says it is still interested in buying nonhealth business of Aetna (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: President Clinton today denounced proposals by Republican members of Congress to help elderly people buy prescription drugs, and he defended his own proposal, saying the government must subsidize drug coverage for all Medicare beneficiaries, not just for those who have modest incomes or use large amounts of medicine. Rather than noting their similar goals, Mr. Clinton emphasized the differences between his approach and that of Republicans in Congress.
docs.abstract: Pres Clinton denounces proposals by Republican members of Congress to help elderly people buy prescription drugs, while defending his own proposal; says government must subsidize drug coverage for all Medicare beneficiaries, not only those who have modest incomes or use large amounts of medicine; says Republican approach, to give Federal grants to states to help low-income elderly people buy drugs, would help only poorest seniors while leaving those just above poverty line to fend for themselves; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: U.S. Decides to Support German as Head of I.M.F. President Clinton told Germany's chancellor that he would accept Horst Kohler as the new managing director of the International Monetary Fund, ending a heated diplomatic contest over who would lead the institution that battles global financial crises.

docs.lead_paragraph: The initials H.M.O. stand for health maintenance organization, but where, I'd like to know, is the ''health maintenance'' these organizations are supposed to provide? Despite the extensive reorganization of medical care that this country has witnessed in recent years, the system remains penny-wise and pound-foolish. And you, the consumer, are paying the price -- with your health as well as through your pocket. A lot of negative publicity has been given to the fact that, under so-called managed care, even people in need of urgent care often have to take extreme measures before they get optimal treatment or referral to an appropriate specialist. But not enough attention has been paid to the failure of medical insurers to cover the costs of keeping people healthy.

headline.main: A Big Maintenance Problem at the H.M.O.

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on problems besetting health consumers who use health maintenance orgns; holds that despite extensive reorganization of medical care that this country has witnessed in recent years, system remains penny-wise and pound-foolish, and that consumer is paying price--with his health as well as through his pocket; warns that not enough attention has been paid to failure of medical insurers to cover costs of keeping people healthy; photo (M)

keywords.value: HEALTH MAINTENANCE ORGANIZATIONS AND MANAGED CARE

docs.lead_paragraph: Struggling to keep control of its business, Aetna Inc., the nation's largest health insurer, yesterday rejected a $9.9 billion takeover offer and announced plans to split the 147-year-old company into independent health care and financial services companies this year. Each new company would have its own stock. Aetna also said it would sell some of its overseas health care units and use the money to reduce debt and buy back stock later this year. Aetna wants to placate worried investors who have driven its stock price down, leading to the replacement of its chief executive late last month. Less than a week after that leadership change, Aetna confirmed reports that it had received an offer to discuss a takeover from Wellpoint Health Networks, a health insurance company based in California, and the ING Group, a Dutch financial services company.

headline.main: AETNA FENDS OFF A TAKEOVER OFFER AND PLANS A SPLIT

docs.abstract: Aetna Inc rejects $9.9 billion takeover offer from Wellpoint Health Networks and ING Group, and announces plans to split company into independent health care and financial services organizations, with each having its own stock; will sell some overseas health care units and use money to help reduce debt and buck bay stock later in year; securities analysts say move is unlikely to satisfy investors, who have been clamoring for breakup of company and sale of various divisions, possibly in auction; graph (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: WARREN E. BUFFETT is not particularly enamored of the stocks that Berkshire Hathaway now owns, even though they have declined substantially in price. But he has found a stock he thinks is cheap -- one that Berkshire may begin buying soon: Berkshire Hathaway's own shares. Last year was a dreadful one for Berkshire. Its major 1998 acquisition, General Re, had poor results and many of the stocks in the portfolio that brought fame and wealth to Mr. Buffett, the Berkshire chairman and chief executive, lost value even while the overall market was rising. Over all, Berkshire reported profits of $1.56 billion, or $1,025 a share, in 1999, down from $2.83 billion, or $2,262 a share a year earlier.

headline.main: Market Place; Berkshire Hathaway considers buying back some of its own shares.

docs.abstract: Market Place column on Warren E Buffett's reported plans to buy back some Berkshire Hathaway shares after year in which many stocks in Berkshire Hathaway portfolio lost value, even while overall market was rising; as result, Berkshire's Class A stock fell during year for first time since 1990, and it has continued to fall this year; Buffett has legendary status as investor (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Representative Nita M. Lowey and Senator Charles E. Schumer, both Democrats, have released a report, prepared by a Congressional committee, on the difference in the cost of prescription drugs for people not covered by insurance plans, which includes many elderly patients, and large health organizations. It concluded that those who pay for their own drugs are typically charged more than twice as much or more as health maintenance organizations and the federal government.

Berzon, a San Francisco lawyer, to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, which covers California and several Western states. Approved 64 to 34, March 9.

docs.lead_paragraph: SHORTLY after sundown on Dec. 9, a diner walked into Banania Cafe on Smith Street in Brooklyn, sat at a corner table and ordered oysters. Ten minutes later, the oysters, fried in cornmeal, arranged on a bed of celery root puree and dappled with a tomato-seed vinaigrette, arrived from the kitchen. They were placed in front of the man, Joseph Gannascoli, who ate them and pronounced them ''sublime.'' If it was the most mundane of transactions between eater and eatery, one played out millions of times each day. It was also a milestone for Danforth Houle, the bistro's chef and owner.

headline.main: On Smith Street, a Dream Made Real

docs.abstract: Danforth Houle opens Banania Cafe in Brooklyn, the culmination of a dream he has had since his teens; opening follows a year of fruitless search for a site in Manhattan and countless hours of work and planning at his Carroll Gardens site; photos (L)
